name: Bighorn Sheep
description: It has an overall brown coloration, white around the muzzle and snout, and a white rump. Both males and females have horns.
spread_note: Rocky mountain slopes of North America, from Canada to Mexico; our subspecies inhabits desert regions in the southwest USA and northern Mexico.
food_note: Grass and low herbs, occasionally cacti
image_alt: Bighorn Sheep, photo: Marieke IJsendoorn Kuijpers
proportions: Body length 140–200 cm; tail length 8–12 cm; weight 30–230 kg
reproduction: Females are pregnant for an average of 170–180 days and bear 1 young (rarely 2).
attractions: Bighorn sheep are renowned for the fierce battles of the males. The size of the horns (up to 1.1 m and 14 kg) determines the males’ social status. The desert subspecies we keep also uses its horns to crush cacti. Females seek secluded spots to give birth, and the young can follow their mother over difficult terrain soon after birth.
breeding: We have kept them since 2009, with one young raised in both 2012 and 2013.
